channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: As Iran’s Government Tries to Quell Protests, Accounts of Brutal Crackdown Emerge
item.description: As many as 3,000 feared dead as witnesses describe government forces firing on unarmed protesters.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Farnaz Fassihi, Sanam Mahoozi and Sanjana Varghese
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: via Reuters
item.media:description: An image taken from social media and verified by The New York Times shows people looking for relatives as bodies piled up outside Tehran’s forensics laboratory on Sunday.

item.title: At This Office Park, Scamming the World Was the Business
item.description: Times journalists got a rare look inside one of the compounds where the online fraud industry makes its billions. Inspirational slogans (“Keep going”) were just the start.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech and Jes Aznar
item.media:description: The Shunda Park scam complex in Karen State, Myanmar, in December.

item.title: Greenland Would Be the Largest U.S. Land Acquisition, if Trump Got His Way
item.description: Denmark does not want to sell its territory. But for a real estate mogul turned president, the world’s largest island may be irresistible.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue commemorating Hans Egede, the Danish missionary who founded Nuuk, the capital of Greenland.

item.title: Marine Le Pen Is Appealing a Decision to Bar Her From Office.
item.description: Ms. Le Pen, whose far-right party leads polls in France, was convicted last year of embezzlement. The outcome of her appeal, which started on Tuesday, will determine if she can run for president next year.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic and Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters with pictures of Marine Le Pen, the French far-right leader, last year after a court barred her from running for office for five years.

item.title: Trump Urges Antigovernment Protesters in Iran to ‘Take Over’
item.description: “HELP IS ON ITS WAY,” President Trump said on social media. He has threatened to intervene militarily on behalf of the protesters if Iran uses lethal force.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Leily Nikounazar
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Getty Images
item.media:description: A burned-out building in Tehran on Saturday. Iran is experiencing the most expansive protests in years against its authoritarian rulers.

item.title: Uganda Cuts Internet Days Before Presidential Election
item.description: The authorities say the decision was made to prevent the spread of misinformation as President Yoweri Museveni seeks his seventh term in office.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Musinguzi Blanshe
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Supporters of Yoweri Museveni cheer during his party’s closing campaign rally on Tuesday ahead of the election in Kampala.

item.title: Trump Says London Is Unsafe. Its Murder Rate Just Hit a Historic Low.
item.description: The city’s homicide rate is lower than that of New York, Paris or Toronto, contradicting a narrative promoted by President Trump and others on the populist right.
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Dearden and Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mounted police on the streets of Harlesden, London, last week.

item.title: How a Syrian Hiking Club Is Rediscovering the Country
item.description: The nearly 14-year civil war prevented Syrians from traveling freely to many parts of their own country. After the conflict ended a year ago, a group of outdoor enthusiasts began exploring newly accessible areas, fueled by a sense of adventure and hope.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Diego Ibarra Sanchez
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times

item.title: Spanish Singer Julio Iglesias Accused of Sexual Assault
item.description: Prosecutors said two former employees of Mr. Iglesias, a renowned Spanish singer, had accused him of abuse. His representatives did not respond to requests for comment.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Bertrand Guay/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The Spanish singer Julio Iglesias performing in Paris in 2003.

item.title: China’s ‘Dr. Frankenstein’ Thinks Time Is on His Side
item.description: He Jiankui spent three years in prison after creating gene-edited babies. Now back at work, he sees a greater opening for researchers who push boundaries.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: He Jiankui, a researcher in gene editing, at his home in Beijing. He argues that his only crime was being ahead of his time in a world not yet ready for his vision.

item.title: Prosecutors Seek Death Penalty for Former South Korea President
item.description: Former President Yoon Suk Yeol faces an insurrection​ charge after his failed attempt to put his country under martial law in 2024.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Ahn Young-Joon/Associated Press
item.media:description: Commuters watched South Korea’s ousted former President Yoon Suk Yeol on television, at a train station in Seoul, the capital, in December.

item.title: Son of Deposed Shah of Iran Seeks Center Stage Amid Protests
item.description: Reza Pahlavi, living in exile in the United States, has long marketed himself as a future leader of Iran. His father’s repressive legacy casts a long shadow.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Isabel Infantes/Reuters
item.media:description: A demonstration in London on Sunday called on the British prime minister to support the Iranian people. Some Iranian protesters have rallied around Reza Pahlavi, the exiled son of the last shah of Iran.

item.title: Trump Says He Will Impose Tariffs on Iran’s Trading Partners: What to Know
item.description: If President Trump follows through, some of Iran’s biggest trading partners, including China and India, could be hit hard.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump is exploring options for diplomacy with Iran as he weighs whether to attack the country to try to deter its leaders from killing more protesters, U.S. officials said.

item.title: Adelaide Writers’ Week Canceled After It Disinvited Palestinian Australian Author
item.description: Organizers said her presence was not “culturally sensitive” after a mass shooting that targeted Jewish Australians. Nearly 200 other writers withdrew in protest.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Gary Francis/Zuma, via Reuters
item.media:description: Adelaide Writers’ Week was canceled on Tuesday, after a decision by organizers raised concerns over free speech.

item.title: Crane Falls on Passenger Train in Thailand, Killing at Least 22
item.description: The railway authorities said there were almost 200 people on the train when the accident happened in Nakhon Ratchasima Province, northeast of Bangkok. Dozens were injured.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Ministry of Transport, via Reuters
item.media:description: A crane fell on a passenger train in Nakhon Ratchasima province in Thailand on Wednesday.

item.title: Iran’s Leaders May Survive Protests. But Anger Will Likely Persist.
item.description: Its security forces have brutally defended the Islamic Republic, but the protests show that many Iranians consider it stagnant and ideologically hollow.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Getty Images
item.media:description: Some parts of Tehran saw heavy damage during protests in recent days.

item.title: Mark Carney Heads to Beijing to Discuss Canada-China Relations as U.S. Outlook Darkens
item.description: The prime minister is seeking new markets for Canadian goods and to mend relations with China after years of deep acrimony between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Yoan Valat
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada and his advisers have said that he is seeking a pragmatic thawing of Canada’s relationship with China.

item.title: China’s Coal Ban Improved Air Quality, but Villagers Are Paying the Price
item.description: China banned the burning of coal for heat around Beijing, but natural gas subsidies have run out, leaving many villagers vulnerable in dangerously cold weather.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of a village in Quyang County, in northern China, soak up the midday sun to try to warm up and reduce their heating costs.

item.title: China Announces Record Trade Surplus as Its Exports Flood World Markets
item.description: China’s surplus reached $1.19 trillion last year, a 20 percent increase from 2024, as Beijing kept the currency weak and pursued self-reliance to replace imports.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The production line at a car factory in Hangzhou, China, in October. Exports to the United States fell, but rose to much of the rest of the world.

item.title: Venezuela Frees Several Americans From Prison, U.S. Says
item.description: They were the first U.S. citizens released after the U.S. military captured Nicolás Maduro and flew him to the United States to stand trial on drug and other charges.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: El Helicoide prison in Caracas, Venezuela, is one of the main prisons in the country holding political prisoners.

item.title: David Webb, Investor Who Took on Hong Kong Tycoons, Dies at 60
item.description: From his internet platform, he became a tenacious watchdog fighting financial regulators for minority shareholders and exposing shady business dealings.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Webb in Hong Kong last May. By the age of 32, he had earned enough money to leave his job and divide his time between managing his investments and monitoring the city’s big financial players.

item.title: Analysis: Trump Supports Protesters in Iran, but Not in Minneapolis
item.description: The split-screen television images of mass demonstrations in Minneapolis and Tehran have highlighted the president’s disparate views of democracy and popular dissent.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: The television images of mass protests in the streets of Minneapolis and Tehran in recent days have invariably highlighted the complications and contradictions of Donald J. Trump’s presidency.

item.title: U.S. to Name Palestinian Committee to Run Gaza
item.description: Officials said the body’s leadership could be announced as soon as Wednesday, but U.S. efforts to shape postwar Gaza by disarming Hamas have faced hurdles.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gaza City on Tuesday. The territory faces major hurdles to rebuilding.

item.title: A Timeline of Protests in Iran
item.description: Amid a near-total communications blackout, witness footage trickling out of Iran paints a picture of how the country’s largest uprising in decades spread — and turned deadly.
item.dc:creator: Monika Cvorak and Sanjana Varghese
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Everyone Wants the Arctic
item.description: President Trump wants to annex Greenland. We look at the fight over a different Arctic territory for insights.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times

item.title: The View From Above Antarctica’s Fastest Melting Glacier
item.description: Times journalists were able to get tantalizingly close to the Thwaites glacier, which scientists are hoping to spend weeks studying up close.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The icebreaker Araon at the Thwaites Glacier in Antarctica on Sunday.

item.title: Arrest Made in Toronto Airport Gold Heist as Police Seek 2 Others
item.description: The Canadian authorities have identified 10 people in connection with the theft of about $14.4 million in gold bars from Toronto Pearson International Airport in 2023.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Carlos Osorio/Reuters
item.media:description: A shipment of gold and money from Switzerland went missing in April 2023 after it was placed in an airport warehouse in Toronto.

item.title: Delta Offers Optimistic Outlook as Travelers Continue to Splurge
item.description: Delta Air Lines said it was expecting profits to rise by around 20 percent in 2026 thanks to strong demand for premium tickets.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Delta Air Lines has enjoyed financial success partly because it caters to travelers who are willing to spend a lot on luxurious seats and airport lounges.

item.title: A Scientific Expedition to Antarctica’s Thwaites Glacier Deals With Weather Hiccups
item.description: The clock is ticking. But low clouds have prevented helicopters from moving scientists and gear onto the continent’s fastest-melting glacier.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Inside a Scam Complex’s Detailed Playbook
item.description: The scammers at a vast office park in Myanmar wielded deepfake technology, doctored videos and pinpoint conversational ploys that differed by the ages and nationalities of their victims.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times

item.title: A Times Reporter Goes Inside a Cyberscam Center in a War Zone
item.description: Hannah Beech, a New York Times reporter, gained rare access to one of Myanmar’s notorious cyberscam centers to see how Chinese criminals have been targeting Americans in the middle of a war zone.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech and Daniel Fetherston
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Attacked Boat With Aircraft That Looked Like a Civilian Plane
item.description: Even accepting the Trump administration’s claim that there is an armed conflict with suspected drug runners, the laws of war bar “perfidy.”
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage, Eric Schmitt, John Ismay, Julian E. Barnes, Riley Mellen and Christiaan Triebert
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth in the Capitol last week.

item.title: Trump Explores Diplomacy With Iran While Weighing Strikes, Officials Say
item.description: The Pentagon is presenting a wider range of strike options to the president than previously reported. Targets could include Iran’s nuclear program and ballistic missile sites.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Tyler Pager and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: UGC, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An image taken from a social media post released on Friday showing demonstrators gathered in Tehran. President Trump has said that he would come to the aid of protesters if the Iranian government used lethal force against them.

item.title: The Global Cost of Futzing With the Fed
item.description: If President Trump succeeds in gaining control of the Federal Reserve, it could have ripple effects beyond U.S. borders.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: Federal Reserve Bank of New York
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times

item.title: World Court Hears Groundbreaking Genocide Case Against Myanmar
item.description: The case was brought to the World Court by a country not directly affected by the alleged genocide of the Rohingya, a precedent for similar claims against other countries, including Israel.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Phil Nijhuis/ANP, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The International Court of Justice began hearing the genocide case against Myanmar, in The Hague, on Monday.

item.title: In Venezuela, Amnesty for Political Prisoners Stokes Hope and Frustration
item.description: Venezuela’s new leaders and President Trump have alluded to a major release of political prisoners, but the liberations have been slow to come.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Miguel Gutierrez/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The opposition politician Juan Pablo Guanipa, in Caracas in 2020.

item.title: Archaeologists Find Large Roman Villa Under Deer Park in Wales
item.description: The unexpected discovery of a well-preserved and fortified villa in Margam Park in South Wales sheds new light on the Roman occupation there, an expert said.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle

item.title: Owner of Swiss Bar Where 40 Died Is Ordered to Jail as a Flight Risk
item.description: Jacques Moretti has been placed in pretrial detention for at least three months. He and his wife, Jessica Moretti, are under investigation over possible negligence.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The police on Jan. 2 outside Le Constellation bar in Crans-Montana, Switzerland, where a fire had swept through New Year’s celebrations.

item.title: Trump’s Envoy to India Offers Hope Amid a Strained Relationship
item.description: Sergio Gor, a confidant of the U.S. president, took up his post as ambassador in New Delhi with ties between the countries at their lowest ebb in decades.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Manish Swarup/Associated Press
item.media:description: The new U.S. envoy to India, Sergio Gor, delivering a speech Monday at the embassy in New Delhi. President Trump has slapped punitive tariffs on India for buying Russian oil.

item.title: Elon Musk’s X Under UK Investigation Over Grok’s Sexualized A.I. Images
item.description: A British regulator said it had started a formal investigation into Mr. Musk’s chatbot over the spread of illegal images.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Andria Lo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Grok’s prompt page on a phone. In recent weeks, the chatbot has posted sexualized photos of real people, including children, in response to user prompts.

item.title: Venezuela Frees 24 More Political Prisoners, Rights Group Says
item.description: Since an interim government began the releases last week, at least 41 people have been let go, according to Foro Penal.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Family members of political prisoners waiting for releases outside the Rodeo I prison on Friday.

item.title: Europe and China Take Step to Resolve Dispute on Electric Vehicles
item.description: The European Commission allowed carmakers to volunteer limits on their imports from China instead of paying tariffs, an arrangement that could help Volkswagen.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Leonhard Simon/Reuters
item.media:description: The Cupra Tavascan, an electric vehicle made by Volkswagen in China, at the Munich auto show in 2023.

item.title: Iran Says It Is Prepared for War but Ready to Negotiate After Trump’s Warnings
item.description: The comments came after President Trump said he was “ looking at some very strong options” to curb the Iranian authorities’ harsh repression of anti-government protests.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Sanam Mahoozi
item.media:credit: Joseph Eid/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Iran’s foreign minister, Abbas Araghchi, in Beirut, Lebanon, last week. On Monday, he expressed an openness to negotiations with the United States.

item.title: Russian Missiles Failed in Venezuela During U.S. Attack
item.description: The Venezuelan regime had high-powered air defense systems from its allies in the Kremlin, but failed to set much of it up.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib, Eric Schmitt, Christiaan Triebert and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: A destroyed Buk launcher at La Carlota air base in Caracas after the U.S. strikes.

item.title: The Weimar Republic Shaped the 20th Century. Can Today’s Leaders Avoid Its Fate?
item.description: A fragile democracy, the Weimar Republic, briefly took hold in Germany before the Nazis seized power. Now, Weimar’s collapse is seen as a warning.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:credit: Lena Mucha for The New York Times
item.media:description: The German National Theater in Weimar, Germany, where leaders met in 1919 to create a new national Constitution.

item.title: Is Grass-Fed Beef Better?
item.description: The idea of cows grazing in a pasture seems idyllic. We asked experts how their emissions stack up compared to factory farms.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.media:credit: Photo by Ruth Fremson/The New York Times

item.title: Deposed Shah’s Son Hopes Trump Will Put Iran Regime ‘Down for Good’
item.description: Reza Pahlavi, once the crown prince of Iran, says protesters there have been emboldened by President Trump suggesting that he could take military action.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Joe Klamar/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Austria displayed images of Reza Pahlavi during a rally on Sunday in support of nationwide protests in Iran.

item.title: Famed Nigerian Author Blames Death of Toddler Son on Negligent Care
item.description: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie is accusing a private hospital in Lagos of administering an overdose of a sedative, prompting an outpouring of complaints by Nigerians about their health care system.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey and Ismail Auwal
item.media:credit: Schaun Champion for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie at her home in Maryland in February.

item.title: Mass Protests in Iran and Trump’s Threats
item.description: A question now hangs over the country: Is Iran the next target of an emboldened U.S. president?
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: UGC, via Associated Press

item.title: As Death Toll Surges in Iran, Leaders Take Tough Line Against Protesters
item.description: Despite an internet blackout, reports are emerging of a rise in deadly violence as protests spurred by economic woes have snowballed into a mass movement.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Sanam Mahoozi
item.media:credit: Irib/Handout, via Via Reuters

item.title: Syrian Military Takes Aleppo Neighborhoods After Clashes With Kurds
item.description: The takeover ended one of the worst outbreaks of violence between the central government and the Kurdish-led forces since the end of the civil war just over a year ago.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Adri Salido/Getty Images
item.media:description: Soldiers of the Syrian army in Aleppo on Saturday, following clashes between government forces and Kurdish fighters.

item.title: Israeli Police Question Top Netanyahu Aide Over Leaked Document Case
item.description: Tzachi Braverman, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s chief of staff, was detained for questioning on Sunday over accusations that he sought to impede an investigation.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Ohad Zwigenberg/Associated Press
item.media:description: Tzachi Braverman (standing), the chief of staff to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, was interviewed by the police on Sunday.

item.title: Malaysia and Indonesia Block Access to Grok Because of Sexually Explicit Content
item.description: Grok, the chatbot created by Elon Musk’s artificial intelligence company, has produced a flood of explicit images featuring real people in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Andria Lo for The New York Times
item.media:description: The prompt page for Grok, the A.I. chatbot made by xAI.

item.title: Trump Shakes up Latin American Politics
item.description: The U.S. capture of Nicolás Maduro has divided the region. But every nation wants to avoid being next.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Government supporters calling for the release of Nicolás Maduro in Caracas, Venezuela, last week.

item.title: Are You Fat Enough to Play in This Soccer League?
item.description: Man v Fat, a soccer league founded in Britain a decade ago, is expanding in the United States, bringing with it a self-deprecating approach to shedding pounds.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: It’s all fun, games and fat-burning as Fat Man United competes against Totten-Ham and Cheese in suburban Dallas.

item.title: Trump Threats and Venezuela Strike Leave Mexico Agonizing Over How to Respond
item.description: President Claudia Sheinbaum and her inner circle have been grappling with the right tone to strike in the country’s response to the Venezuela strike for fear of antagonizing the White House.
item.dc:creator: Paulina Villegas and James Wagner
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Claudia Sheinbaum of Mexico has tried to thread a narrow diplomatic needle in the aftermath of the U.S. strike in Venezuela.

item.title: Latin America Reacts to Trump’s Interventionism
item.description: Jack Nicas, our Mexico City bureau chief, walks us through the ways Latin American leaders are reacting to the Trump administration’s attack on Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Rebecca Suner, James Surdam and Edward Vega

item.title: A Russian Videographer Reveals How Putin Shapes the Next Generation
item.description: Pavel Talankin was a school events coordinator and videographer. When Russia overhauled the curriculum to make students into patriotic soldiers, he kept his camera rolling. The footage became a film that is shortlisted for an Oscar.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Sasha Maslov for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’m just standing there filming and I understand that what’s getting into the camera isn’t just a lesson, but history,” Pavel Talankin said.

item.title: Schools in Occupied Ukraine Aim to Turn Children Into Russian Nationalists
item.description: Required lessons are heavy on militarism and pro-Russian, anti-Ukrainian propaganda. Some people make an arduous escape, partly to avoid the indoctrination.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: Sasha Maslov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tetiana, 37, and her two daughters after crossing from Belarus into Ukraine, in December.
